responses: Hi there, how can I help?
You can ask anything related to COVID'19 Symptoms Allergies Vaccines”,'Offering support for delivering any information regarding COVID’19
COVID-19, otherwise known as coronavirus disease 2019, is a new infectious disease caused by a previously unknown virus called SARS-CoV-2.

patterns: When did COVID’19 start?“,”What is the origin of COVID’19?
responses: The virus was discovered in Wuhan, China in December 2019 and has since spread around the world

patterns: How do the virus spread?”, “How does a person get infected?“,“How does the virus escalate?
responses: COVID-19 is thought to spread mainly through close contact from person to person, including between people who are physically near each other (within about 6 feet). People who are infected but do not show symptoms can also spread the virus to others

patterns: What are some of the symptoms of COVID’19?“, “List down the symptoms of COVID’19
What are the symptoms of someone infected with a coronavirus?
What signs a person shows when he is infected with COVID’19?
responses: It depends on the virus, but common signs include respiratory symptoms, fever, cough, shortness of breath, and breathing difficulties. In more severe cases, infection can cause pneumonia, severe acute respiratory syndrome, kidney failure and even death.

patterns: Is there a treatment for a novel coronavirus?
Can a person be treated when contacted with coronavirus?
Is there a cure for COVID’19?
responses: There is no specific treatment for disease caused by a novel coronavirus. However, many of the symptoms can be treated and therefore treatment based on the patient’s clinical condition. Moreover, supportive care for infected persons can be highly effective.

patterns: When do symptoms start to appear?
In how much time the symptoms start to show?
responses: The average time for symptoms of COVID-19 to develop is five to six days, but it can take up to 14 days for people to show symptoms.

patterns: What should I do if I think I have COVID’19?
What to do if you are not sure whether you have contacted the virus or not?
responses: If you think you have COVID-19, stay at home and self-isolate – even if your symptoms are mild.If you have symptoms of COVID-19 or have been in close contact with someone who has symptoms or has tested positive, call your health care provider to see if and when you should take a test.The people you live with will also need to stay home for at least 14 days from when you first developed symptoms.Avoid close contact with others in your household while you’re ill.Stay one metre apart, or in another room if possible. If you live with someone who’s more vulnerable, try to arrange for them to stay elsewhere. You can also wear a medical mask to reduce the risk of infection.

patterns: What are some of the precautions to take for COVID’19?
How can someone save themselves from the novel coronavirus?
responses: To prevent the spread of COVID-19:1)Clean your hands often. Use soap and water, or an alcohol-based hand rub.2)Maintain a safe distance from anyone who is coughing or sneezing 3)Wear a mask when physical distancing is not possible.4)Don’t touch your eyes, nose or mouth.5)Cover your nose and mouth with your bent elbow or a tissue when you cough or sneeze.6)Stay home if you feel unwell.7)If you have a fever, cough and difficulty breathing, seek medical attention.

patterns: Is there a vaccine for COVID’19?
Are scientist able to find a vaccine against the novel coronavirus?
responses: The first COVID-19 vaccines are now being distributed in some countries.COVID-19 vaccines work by helping your body develop immunity to the virus that causes COVID-19.This means your body will be ready and will be able to respond faster to the virus if you are exposed to it,so you’re less likely to get seriously ill.

patterns: Is it safe to vaccinate yourself?
Is it safe to use a vaccine that has been manufactured in such a short time?
Can children also be vaccinated with the new vaccine?
responses: All three vaccines authorized for emergency use by the Food and Drug Administration (FDA) have been thoroughly tested and found to be safe and effective in preventing severe COVID-19. They continue to undergo continuous and intense safety monitoring.Safety trials begin in the lab, with tests and research on cells and animals, before moving on to human studies.
